#MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	582	This is not an amendment. We will come to that later. We are on section 1.

#TomFleming	unknown-#TomFleming-party	unknown-#TomFleming-dob	unknown-#TomFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	583	The radon problem in County Kerry has had very serious consequences in the last ten years
column2: in particular. It has claimed a number of lives
column3: for instance
column4: and is seriously affecting the general health of people who are unfortunate to be living in areas affected by the gas. Time will tell regarding the overall implications for the general public who have to live in houses affected by radon. It is a modern phenomenon because of the high standard of housing and of insulation in particular. Given the huge cost of energy and of oil in particular
column5: people have a very high level of insulation in their homes but the side effect of this is that the radon is trapped in the houses. People are very unfortunate to be in this situation. Perhaps their houses are not worthless
column6: as the Minister has said
column7: but they are hugely devalued
column8: which is the kernel of the problem. Some mechanism will have to be worked out to make allowances for a large proportion of the population of County Kerry. Remediation measures can be carried out but they are not 100% effective and are very costly as they rely on electricity to power fans to extract the air. There is a very serious disincentive in the Bill to carry out remediation works or general improvements in so far as they could raise the value of the house
column9: which obviously has implications for the householder.For example
column10: this may happen if people need to build extensions to family homes. This tax will be a significant deterrent. The construction industry is currently on its knees and we should not be putting any impediments in the way of people trying to create activity in building. We need to examine the matter carefully
column11: as every job
column12: no matter how small
column13: can be priceless because of the high unemployment rate in the country. This tax will be a serious deterrent. I even have reservations about the high valuation and tax rate on mansions. Mr. Michael Flatley came to Castle Hyde in Fermoy
column14: and he deserves to be applauded for what has been done there. He is a major asset to the area and has boosted the economy by engaging builders and other workers. We should encourage such activity. If we are to get in foreign direct investment
column15: we cannot put obstacles in their way. Many of these people demand larger houses because parent company employees
column16: such as directors or managers
column17: may visit and they need to be entertained. It is a ridiculous measure.

column1: #MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	584	I will comment on the section and the Bill in general. It is fine for the Minister
column2: Deputy Noonan
column3: to wax lyrical about the Dodder and the amendments tabled by Opposition Deputies. We all appreciate his good humour and can go back to when he was a Minister 20 years ago to recall "Scrap Saturday" and the humour and sarcasm in that. I respect what the Minister is trying to do but I do not respect the way the Bill has been guillotined and forced through.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	585	This is a definition section.

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	586	There are 63 amendments to be discussed in such a short time
column2: which is extremely unfair. On the night this tax was mooted in the budget
column3: where was the Minister
column4: Big Phil the enforcer
column5: but in Doha at some kind of a world conference. That is how little he perceives the trauma being experienced by people. The Minister mentioned houses flooded by the Dodder but there are hundreds of houses threatened in Clonmel all the time whose owners cannot get insurance. Large sums of money have been spent but those people have not been recognised by the Minister.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	587	They have the same recognition.

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	588	People whose houses are affected by radon have not been recognised. I welcome the consideration given by the Minister to the voluntary housing sector
column2: etc. but the Bill is draconian nevertheless. Giving the Revenue Commissioners power to enter people's homes is a retrograde step. I have stated in other debates that I am self-employed and I am used to dealing with the Revenue Commissioners in my premises because I operate a business from the home. That is fine. The vast majority of home owners are in negative equity and are in appalling debt positions
column3: leading to awful trauma
column4: including marriage break-ups and many suicides. The Minister is aware of that. Nevertheless
column5: we expect these people to get letters in the next week or two from the Revenue Commissioners. Anybody who gets a letter from the Revenue Commissioners would regard it as serious
column6: and people may not know what to make of a house tax
column7: self-assessment and valuation. These people have many bills already
column8: which they cannot pay
column9: and to get another like this amounts to heavy-handed tactics. The coalition in the 1980s was accused of this in another way. I have argued more than once that the Minister's party and the Labour Party are punishing the electorate for having the audacity not to give them a turn in government for 14 years. The Minister for Justice and Equality
column10: Deputy Shatter
column11: mentions the 14 years every day. The public shares this view that members of Fine Gael and the Labour Party were so long in the wilderness - some Members are now approaching pension age - that the Government has decided to teach the public a lesson. On the front page of a newspaper the Minister
column12: Big Phil the enforcer
column13: indicated he would teach the media a lesson.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	589	You should use the term "Minister".

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	590	Of course. I always call him the Minister. He is the Minister for the Environment
column2: Community and Local Government but he was in Doha when we discussed the matter in the budget. That is how much he cared about the ordinary people and the home owners in a perilous position. The Taoiseach did not help this morning when Deputy Boyd Barrett tried to raise the issue. He scoffed
column3: laughed
column4: joked and sneered about standing at some tree
column5: looking at a house in the distance with tinted glasses. I did not know what he was talking about. The Taoiseach must return to reality quite fast as he and some of his Ministers - although not all - are on an ego trip. The adrenaline has been evident since this time two years ago
column6: when the parties got into power. The Government parties must face reality or they will find out the feelings of the public. I hate mentioning this on the day when the by-election writ was moved following the death of Deputy Shane McEntee
column7: who was a friend. The Government will get answers if the letters arrive before the canvassing leaflets. I suppose they will not arrive before the leaflets. Maybe there will be a phone call to the Revenue Commissioners to back away. The enforcers are in charge and the little people do not matter any more. The people up the tree-lined avenues with daffodils interest those enforcers. They are the mansions. My colleague
column8: Deputy Tom Fleming
column9: mentioned Michael Flatley
column10: who is nimble-footed and a good little dancer. The Government representatives will be dancing in public when they meet the people because they are waiting. I hope the Government has good dancers and runners because they will be getting it. I do not say this for fun but people are in a perilous position. I was in the home village of the Chief Whip in Wexford last night. The people there cannot find him because he is too busy in Dublin
column11: or so he says. They will find him because he will have to knock on doors again. The property tax will meet the Government in the face and it will not be a case of "Mary
column12: how are you
column13: how are you doing
column14: how are things?" It will get its answers. The Minister's party has always treated the ordinary people with disdain
column15: even going back to the time of shirts of a different colour. I will not mention them but he knows what I am talking about. The party has not changed its spots
column16: which is a pity.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	591	The Deputy should stick to the Bill.

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	592	People are making an effort to work their way out of problems and they are willing to pay. Nevertheless
column2: they cannot take this as they will be driven completely to penury. The Revenue Commissioners and banks will be after these people
column3: along with sheriffs and illegal bandits recovering debts. Those bandits are not subject to any Garda clearance. If a person is to work in a crèche or on a FÁS scheme sweeping the road
column4: there must be Garda clearance-----

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	593	The Deputy is moving away from the section.

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	594	We are certainly moving away from it and I am very sorry for that. I beg your indulgence.

#MichaelMcGrath	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-party	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	595	It was only in the last minute.

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	596	The Taoiseach did not help today
column2: which is a pity. Is mór an trua é. The public are watching and it is a shame to see a line of Ministers scoffing and laughing at this. The scoffing will be on the other side of their faces soon enough. They will get the first taste of that when they head to the plains of Meath.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	597	I call Deputy Wallace.

#MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	598	I put my hand up because I thought we had moved to the amendments. I will speak to the amendments at the appropriate time.

#PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	599	We are dealing with section 1 before moving on. The Minister has indicated that this will provide for local services
column2: giving the impression that there is additional money. Those who follow spokespersons on finance know this is not additional money for local authorities
column3: and a new stream of funding will replace a line of money they already had. The Minister mentioned that everybody must pay their fair share with local authority housing
column4: arguing it would be unfair if somebody in a local authority house were not to pay a fair share. The Minister should know that the Bill does not put a charge on a local authority housing tenant but rather on the local authority. The Minister's assumption is that the charge will be passed to local authority tenants
column5: despite the fact that they do not own the home but rather pay rent for the home in which they live. The Minister may be aware that a number of local authorities have passed resolutions relating to what is called a "section 140". The issuing of rents is a function of the management but this takes the power from the manager.A number of local authorities have passed section 140 motions that compel the manager legally not to pass on the charge. I understand those motions have been supported by the parties in government at local authority level. I want the Minister to deal with that because he has made the assumption that the money is additional money for local authorities. I expect many local authorities will be passing the same motions in the forthcoming weeks and months. In Monaghan
column6: for example
column7: Councillor Matt Carthy proposed a motion and it has been accepted by the council. Management says its hands have been legally tied such that it cannot now pass on the charge to tenants. Therefore
column8: the charge will be a charge on the local authority that will take the money from them. On the one hand
column9: some of the money will go to the local authorities but
column10: on the other
column11: it will be taken by the Government as there will be reduced funding. With regard to local authority housing stock
column12: where management cannot pass on the charge to the local authority tenants - it should not be passed on in any case - money will actually have to be given back to the State. They will be at a net loss. Could the Minister explain the position on this? While the Minister is partially correct that the adaptation of a house could devalue it
column13: particularly if kitchens
column14: for example
column15: are lowered for a wheelchair user
column16: I know from experience of cases where adaptation was required for severely disabled or paralysed people. I refer not only to adaptation but also to extensions. An additional room
column17: such as a bathroom
column18: might have to be built on
column19: or slopes or ramps may have to be created. This costs money. If we had time to tick-tack on this issue I believe the Minister would amend the legislation. I do not believe it is his intention to have an impact on the people I describe. I tabled my amendment to the original legislation. I welcome the fact that the amended Bill goes a certain distance but if the Minister considers what he has done he will note that people who got grants to adapt their houses will have the value of the grant subtracted from the value of their property. It will be of benefit. However
column20: people who did not get grants will be in different circumstances. Let us consider the example of Joe and Mary. Joe
column21: who was unemployed and got a grant of €10
column22: 000 to adapt his house under the housing adaptation grant scheme
column23: will be able to subtract €10
column24: 000 from the value of his house when calculating its value and pay the charge on the remainder. Mary
column25: who was working and did not get the adaptation grant because she was means tested
column26: thus forcing her to pay the €10
column28: will not have this sum subtracted from the value of her house. Joe
column29: who got the money from the State to carry out the adaptation
column31: 000 subtracted from the value of his house
column33: who did not get a cent from the State because she was means-tested
column34: will not get anything. It does not make sense. This is a mistake either by the Minister's officials or himself and it should be corrected. While I realise he will not address this now
column35: I ask him to address it in the Seanad.

column1: #DaraMurphy	unknown-#DaraMurphy-party	unknown-#DaraMurphy-dob	unknown-#DaraMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	600	Before the Joint Committee on Finance and the Public Service
column2: the Chairman of the Revenue Commissioners referred to houses at risk of flooding and
column3: more specifically
column4: to insurance cover. The Minister and other Deputies referred to this also. As the Minister will be aware
column5: significant work is planned and ongoing with regard to flood prevention measures. While he indicated that the circumstances of houses whose values may be reduced by virtue of their occupants not having insurance or their living in a flood-risk area may be taken into account
column6: will he clarify that if flood-prevention measures are put in place in some years
column7: thus increasing house values
column8: the former flood risk and lack of insurance availability will be taken into account?

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	601	I call Deputy Mick Wallace
column2: who may speak on section 1.

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	602	I will speak as much on that section as anyone else.

#MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	603	I ask the Deputy to do his best.
#MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	604	I will do my very best
column2: bearing in mind that I probably will not have a chance to speak again on this legislation. If two or three houses in an estate of 40 or 50 have been certified as having pyrite
column3: it is very probable that several others will have a pyrite problem as the same stone will have been used. The ground for each house is not prepared every second day; houses are built together. All houses in affected estates will have received the same treatment
column4: with the same stone. The untreated houses have the same problems coming down the tracks as those already exposed as having pyrite. Aside from the fact that under no circumstances could one dream of selling such a house
column5: unless it is given a certificate proving beyond all doubt that it does not have pyrite
column6: the chance that many of the houses have pyrite is great because the stone will have come from the same quarry and will have been used around the same time. It is completely unfair on the owners. The houses are houses that one would be hard set to give away
column7: unlike the ones to which the Minister referred. Selling a house in an estate where there is pyrite is just about impossible today. I ask the Minister to consider the people caught in this dilemma. It is grossly unfair to expect them to pay a property tax on a property that is in a very difficult set of circumstances through no fault of their own.

column1: #MichaelHealyRae	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-party	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-dob	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	605	I want to clarify a matter for the Minister. He stated he was unsure about what I had said. I said there is no difference between a home affected by pyrite and one affected by radon.

#MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	606	The Deputy has tabled an amendment on this under section 2.

#MichaelHealyRae	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-party	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-dob	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	607	I have but if I do not use the opportunity now to speak about this I will not be able to do so because the Government has imposed a guillotine. I will use the opportunity. We cannot be stopped because there is a race to the bottom as quick as we can go. We must get in our say because we will not get one later. There will be a vote and that will be the end of it. I wish to stress my point to the Minister and I will put it in writing. I do not take on board the Minister's comment on the worth of houses because one can have a house that is worth nothing. Would I
column2: the Minister or any other Member want to buy a home in which somebody has died because of an extant problem with radon? Those affected must pay money every year to try to keep the badness
column3: the gas
column4: at bay. Nobody would want to live in such a house. If I were given one for nothing
column5: I would not want to take it. I would not want anyone in my family to live in one
column6: nor would the Minister or any other Member. What I propose is not opening the floodgates such that thousands of houses will be implicated. Not many houses are affected by radon. The Government should make the same exception for those affected as it made for those whose houses are affected by pyrite. I again compliment the campaigners. What I am trying to do is put right a wrong. The Minister should state he will make an allowance and that there is no difference in the circumstances of those whose houses are affected by pyrite and those whose houses are affected by radon. I have great respect for the Taoiseach but he gave me an ill-informed answer one morning on this issue. Just as Deputy Mick Wallace said pyrite is in the actual building
column7: the Taoiseach said radon is coming from the ground up
column8: thus making the circumstances different. I put it to the Minister that it is all the same; if the house is bad
column9: the house is bad
column10: be it affected by pyrite or radon. If a house is worthless and cannot be sold on the open market because somebody would not want to buy it
column11: surely to God the Minister can take this on board
column12: make an allowance and accept my amendment.

column1: #NoelGrealishPD	unknown-#NoelGrealishPD-party	unknown-#NoelGrealishPD-dob	unknown-#NoelGrealishPD-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	608	In the next two weeks
column2: millions of people will receive letters from the Revenue
column3: 60% of whom have never received a letter from the Revenue before. People do not like getting letters from the Revenue Commissioners and that will have a major effect on people. When they read the small print
column4: it will put the fear of God into many of them
column5: particularly the elderly. I am dealing with a 93 year old lady who is afraid of this letter arriving and who has rung me three times about it. The Bill states that if a person undervalues his house
column6: he will be charged interest and penalties when the house is sold. What about those people who have never broken the law and who do not want to get into trouble with the Revenue Commissioners? If they overvalue their houses for the property tax and their houses are sold for less than the value they estimated
column7: will they get a rebate from the local authority? Every Minister and the Taoiseach has said this is for services within the local community such as roads
column8: lights and footpaths. What about those who live in housing estates governed by management companies who must pay up to €1
column9: 000 in management fees? They will be caught for the property charge as well. In that case
column10: local authorities should take these estates in charge and cover the costs of services in them. The residents should not have to carry the double burden of management fees and local authority property charges when
column11: technically
column12: the local authority will not give them any services. They must pay for the water coming in and going out when water metering is put in place later this year. Not far from me in Galway
column13: 15 houses were flooded in 2009. Only one of those houses can receive any insurance. I raised the issue with the Minister
column14: and he advised me to go to Michael Kemp
column15: the insurance regulator
column16: but he told me he could not do a thing about it
column17: that he had no control over this. Even I
column18: given where I live
column19: received a letter last week from the insurance company and if I am flooded
column20: half of Galway city will be flooded. I was informed that I will not receive flood cover. I do not mind and I wrote back to ask what the insurance company will knock off my house if it would not cover me for flood damage because I know it will not be flooded. These houses are now worthless
column21: as Deputy Dara Murphy has said. If the owners went to sell them
column22: no one would buy them. I compliment the OPW on doing tremendous flood alleviation work in the locality but it will not give anyone the confidence to buy one of those houses. Those people must be given some consideration because they live in houses that are worthless.

column1: #DaraMurphy	unknown-#DaraMurphy-party	unknown-#DaraMurphy-dob	unknown-#DaraMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	609	I did not say they are worthless. I said they would be worth more when the flood prevention measures are put in place.

#NoelGrealishPD	unknown-#NoelGrealishPD-party	unknown-#NoelGrealishPD-dob	unknown-#NoelGrealishPD-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	610	I am saying they are worthless.

#StephenDonnelly	unknown-#StephenDonnelly-party	unknown-#StephenDonnelly-dob	unknown-#StephenDonnelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	611	One of the most contentious issues is that people in areas like Dublin and Wicklow will pay several times more than people in the Minister's own constituency. In his answer to questions on that issue
column2: on which I have tabled amendments
column3: the Minister said the reason those people pay more is because the higher value of the house is a function of higher local services. The Minister and I both know that not only is that not the case
column4: the opposite is the case. The councils do not pay more money to provide better services in areas where the house prices are higher. The spend per person for Dublin City Council is less than anywhere else. Were we to follow the Minister's logic
column5: I would agree that the money should be used to pay for local services but that is not what will happen. I appeal to the Minister to apply his own logic to this and if he is going to charge people
column6: to charge them for the services provided and do not charge people in Dublin
column7: Wicklow and other urban areas several times more for services that not only do not cost several times more
column8: but cost less because of economies of scale.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	612	There are many questions and I will try to get through them and be as helpful as I can.

#MichaelHealyRae	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-party	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-dob	unknown-#MichaelHealyRae-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	613	If the Minister lifted the guillotine he would be fine.

#MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	614	The big difference between pyrite damaged homes and homes that have a radon gas problem is that according to the Department of the Environment
column2: Community and Local Government
column3: the radon gas problem can be remediated at very low cost
column4: whereas pyrite is far more expensive. I rely on the technical information on housing from the Department and the note it provided on radon gas states that high radon levels in homes are easy to identify and
column5: once identified
column6: are relatively simple to fix. The testing of houses for radon is relatively straightforward and non-invasive. It is also inexpensive
column7: with tests costing around €56. If the radon levels are found to be below the natural reference levels
column8: no further action is necessary. Where radon levels are found to be high
column9: the installation of an active radon sump is the most common and effective remediation method in Ireland. A sump can be installed within a day and with little disruption to the house as the work is carried out outside the house. This method can reduce the highest radon concentrations typically by 90%. An alternative approach is to increase indoor ventilation
column10: which can reduce radon levels by up to 50%
column11: thus being suitable for homes with up to twice the national reference level. The national radon control strategy for Ireland is the most appropriate way to address the issue of radon contamination and I do not feel it appropriate to provide exemptions from the local property tax to cater for this issue. The local property tax is a self-assessment tax based on the market value of property. In the first instance
column12: it will be a matter for the liable person to calculate the tax due based on his or her assessment of the market value of property. It is not similar to pyrite and according to the Department it can be remediated at very low cost.

column2: Community and Local Government that I have a letter on this topic from a man whose wife died because of radon in his house. I am sorry for interrupting but it is very emotional issue when someone dies in a house and the Department does not seem to understand that.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2013-03-05 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	616	I know it is emotional but according to the technical people in the Department of the Environment
column2: Community and Local Government
column3: if there are high levels of radon in a house
column4: they can be fixed at low cost. A test to establish the level of radon in a house can be done for €56. This is a different case from pyrite
column5: and while there will be an exemption for homes affected by pyrite
column6: there will be no exemption from radon. Of course
column7: if someone thinks the problem with radon has significantly reduced the value of his home
column8: that will be reflected in the value he attributes to the house and if he puts a short note to that effect on the return
column9: that will be taken into account. Deputy Fleming suggested householders will be deterred from building extensions because of the property tax but that will not be the case. The initial valuation in 2013 will stand for three years so any extension built during that period will not lead to an increase in the payment in that time. It is also unlikely the full cost of an extension would be added to the full market value of a property
column10: even in the next valuation period of 2016 because extensions
column11: as we know
column12: do not always enhance the value of houses. Frequently
column13: they do not enhance by the amount the extension costs. Deputy Mattie McGrath mentioned the Revenue interfering in the by-election process. He probably did not mean that as a serious charge but I must put on record that Revenue is statutorily independent in carrying out its duties and there can be no question of interfering with the basis on which it administers the tax system in the context of by-elections or any other circumstances.
